This study investigates the influence of palladium (Pd) doping on Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, combining comprehensive experimental characterizations with theoretical insights. The catalysts, synthesized with varying Pd loadings (0–3 wt.%), were evaluated across 210–250 °C. Catalytic performance analysis revealed that 2 wt.% Pd (CZZPd2) demonstrated superior CO2 conversion (22%) and methanol selectivity (64%) at 240 °C, achieving the highest methanol space-time yield (7.54 mmol/g.cat/hr). Characterization techniques, including XRD, XPS, TEM, CO2-TPD, and H2-TPR, highlighted the critical role of Pd in enhancing hydrogen spillover, stabilizing Cu active sites, and promoting optimal oxygen vacancy formation, which collectively facilitated intermediate stabilization and reduced the apparent activation energy (Ea = 52 kJ/mol) for methanol synthesis. In-situ DRIFTS validated the stabilization of key reaction intermediates (formate and methoxide) on CZZPd2, correlating with its superior catalytic performance. DFT calculations provided atomic-level insights, illustrating the synergistic electronic interaction between Pd, Cu, and ZnO, which optimally lowers the energy barrier for CO2 activation and methanol formation. Excessive Pd loading (CZZPd3) led to particle agglomeration, disrupted metal-oxide interactions, and increased activation energy, reducing methanol selectivity. These findings highlight the important role of Pd in shaping the structure and electronic properties of the catalyst, making CZZPd2 as a benchmark catalyst for efficient and selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst surface basicity CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Pd doped Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts DFT Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The heavy reliance on fossil fuels has led to a significant rise in atmospheric CO2 levels, now at 420 ppm, leading to major environmental challenges like global warming and climate change [1]. Addressing these challenges requires innovative and sustainable solutions. One promising approach is carbon capture, utilization, and sequestration (CCUS), which not only reduces CO2 emissions but also views CO2 as a valuable resource for producing chemicals and fuels [2,3]. Among these solutions, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol has emerged as a viable option. This process recycles CO2, providing a renewable energy source and chemicals while seamlessly integrating into existing industrial infrastructure to help reduce CO2 emissions [4,5]. Methanol, a C1 alcohol, is a versatile chemical with diverse applications. It is widely used as a solvent, chemical intermediate, and drop-in fuel substitute. Methanol also serves as a key precursor for producing secondary chemicals such as olefins, formaldehyde, formic acid, and acetic acid, essential building blocks for various industrial processes [6–8]. Methanol can also be utilized as a drop-in fuel or transformed into other fuels like gasoline, diesel, and ethers, providing a potential alternative to fossil fuels [9–11]. Its global production is projected to exceed 120 MT annually by 2025 and is expected to reach 500 MT by 2050, reflecting its growing importance in the energy and chemical sectors [12]. Moreover, methanol is also recognized as a reliable storage medium and carrier for renewable energy due to its established infrastructure, compatibility, operational safety compared to hydrogen, and high-volume energy density [13,14]. Cu-based catalysts have attracted significant research interest for CO2 hydrogenation due to their excellent catalytic activity and high methanol selectivity. Traditional Cu/Zn/Al (CZA) catalysts, widely used for CO-mediated methanol production, have also been adapted for CO2 hydrogenation. However, these catalysts often suffer from rapid deactivation caused by reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, which generates CO while reducing methanol yield [15–18]. To mitigate these issues, researchers have explored replacing Al with Zr to form Cu/Zn/Zr (CZZ) catalysts, introducing multiple active interfaces (Cu/Zn, Cu/Zr, and Zn/Zr). In these systems, Zr helps stabilize smaller Cu species, enhances hydrogen spillover for formate hydrogenation, and provides oxygen vacancies for better CO2 adsorption. The Zn/Zr interface is crucial for formate activation at the Cu/Zn interface. The ternary Cu/Zn/Zr interface also improves water tolerance and copper dispersion, reducing sintering under reaction conditions and further extending catalyst stability [19–24]. Cu/Zn/Zr catalysts have been further enhanced by various additives such as Al, B, Ga, Gd, In, Mg, and Mn [25,26]. These additions enhance catalytic activity, prolong catalyst lifespan, and improve resistance to CO2 while minimizing water adsorption, which otherwise hinders methanol production. Pd-doped Cu/Zn/Zr catalysts have attracted significant attention to enhance methanol selectivity and conversion. This improvement is primarily due to their excellent hydrogenation activity, which facilitates the formation of critical intermediates such as formates and methoxides essential for methanol production. The addition of palladium (Pd) increases the hydrogen availability on the catalyst surface and improves the interaction at the Cu–Pd interface [27,28]. Furthermore, nanostructured catalysts with Pd doping enhance CO₂ activation and catalytic efficiency by creating more active sites for intermediate formation. Additional modifications, including optimizing electronic properties and enhancing metal-support interactions, further stabilize these intermediates, improving catalytic performance [29–31]. Surface basicity has also emerged as one of the critical factors in enhancing the catalytic performance for selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Studies highlight that basic sites on catalysts are essential in enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation by facilitating acid-base interactions. For example, Mg and Zn have been found in strengthening surface basicity thereby enhancing methanol selectivity by promoting active site availability for CO2 adsorption and reducing water adsorption. Furthermore, the incorporation of Ce into catalysts not only improves essential site density but enhances the interaction between Cu and support materials, significantly boosting catalytic stability and methanol production efficiency. The role of basic sites extends to controlling reaction intermediates, as observed in Al-supported systems, where increased surface basicity inhibits the RWGS reaction and improves methanol yield [32–36]. These findings suggest the need to optimize the surface basicity to create efficient and selective catalysts for CO2 utilization. Additionally, the performance and methanol selectivity of Pd-modified copper-based systems depend heavily on the choice of support and catalyst preparation method [37,38]. Traditional methods of preparing Cu-based catalysts, such as co-precipitating Pd with Cu-Zn-Al nitrate solutions or impregnating Cu/Zn metal oxides, have resulted in unsatisfactory Pd utilization. Pd atoms located near active copper species in the catalyst facilitate hydrogen spillover, improving catalytic performance. However, Pd atoms located inside or at a distance from Cu nanoparticles act as inactive spectators, leading to wasted Pd [39]. This inefficiency has driven growing interest in developing more effective Cu-based systems that optimize Pd usage, strengthen Pd-Cu interactions, and improve methanol production efficiency from CO2 hydrogenation. In this study, a series of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 (CZZ) systems doped with palladium (Pd) were synthesized using the evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. This unique synthesis technique allows precise control over catalyst morphology and the distribution of active sites, resulting in highly dispersed and stable structures. The EISA process forms uniform mesoporous frameworks that stabilize smaller Cu nanoparticles, promote strong Pd–Cu interactions, and increase the density of active sites [40,41]. Although Cu-based catalysts with Pd have been studied for CO2 hydrogenation through hydrogen spillover, the specific role of Pd in improving hydrogen spillover and incresaing surface basicity is still not fully understood. To address this, our study investigates Pd doping varied from 0–3 wt.%, synthesized using the EISA method, which enhances surface basicity by creating well-ordered porous structures that improve CO2 adsorption and activation. The comprehensive characterization was conducted to understand the relationship between surface basicity, Pd–Cu interactions, and catalytic activity. This approach aims to optimize Pd doping and utilize surface basicity to enhance CO2 adsorption capacity, improve hydrogenation efficiency, and increase resistance to catalyst deactivation under studied reaction conditions. Additionally, kinetic studies, in-situ DRIFTS and density functional theory (DFT) simulations were employed to study how Pd doping affects CO2 adsorption and methanol production. Activation energy measurements revealed the energy barriers for methanol synthesis, in-situ DRIFTS provided insights into surface interactions during the reaction, and DFT simulations analyzed the energy barriers for CO2 adsorption. 2 Experiment 2.1 Reagents and materials In the present work, all required reagents and chemicals were obtained from Sigma Aldrich with a purity of 99.99%. Distilled water and A.R. grade ethanol at 99.99% purity were used during the synthesis process. The mixture of 20%CO2, 60%H2 & 20%N2 cylinder is purchased from Sigma Gas services with high purity (99.999 %) for reaction. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The CZZ-Pd catalysts (Cu 36%, Zn 18%, Zr 43–46%, and Pd 1–3% by weight) were synthesized using the evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. These catalysts are coded as CZZ-Pd1, CZZ-Pd2, and CZZ-Pd3, where number represents the percentage of Pd added to the base catalyst Cu/ZnO/ZrO2. The detailed compositions of the synthesized catalysts, including the exact concentrations of Cu, Zn, Zr, and Pd, are provided in Table 1 . In the synthesis process, a calculated amount of zirconium precursor (Zr[OC(CH3)3]4) was mixed with 50 mL of ethanol, followed by stirring for 1 hour. Subsequently, 2 mL of concentrated HNO₃ was added and stirred again for another 2 hours at room temperature. Meanwhile, 2 g of heated triblock copolymer P123 and 50 mL of ethanol were mixed and kept for stirring till a transparent solution formed. The mixture was subsequently kept for stirring for another hour at room temperature. After this, the precursors of copper (Cu(NO3)2.xH2O), zinc (Zn(NO3)2.xH2O), and palladium (Pd(NO3)2.xH2O) were mixed in P123 solution, and stirred for 2 hrs. The two solutions were then mixed drop by drop while stirring continuously. After mixing, the combined solution was allowed to stir overnight. The solution was then poured into a Petri dish for solvent evaporation at 50 °C. Once most of the solvent had evaporated, the gel was kept at 80–90 °C for further drying. The final catalyst was obtained by calcining the dried gel in air at 350 °C for 4 hours. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystallinity of the as-synthesized materials was examined by a Proto advanced X-ray diffractometer with a copper Kα radiation source, recording diffracted peaks in the 2θ range of 10-80°. The metallic Cu particle size was also determined using Scherrer analysis based on the XRD peak broadening, given by: (i) L = K λ β cos θ where L represents the crystallite size, K is the form factor, β is the width of the selected peak, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray source, and θ is the Bragg diffraction angle of the maximum peak. Surface area measurements of the catalysts were conducted by Micromeritics ASAP 2020, using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at -195 °C, with degassing of samples for 3 hours at 200 °C. The BJH equation and BET model determined the pore size distribution and surface area, respectively. Particle morphology was examined via TEM (JEM 2100, JEOL, Japan) through the dispersion of samples in ethanol, followed by placing them on lacey carbon formvar-coated copper grids. To assess the electronic state of active metals and surface composition, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) with a Thermo Scientific Kα instrument, having binding energy measured to an experimental error of ±0.1 eV, with C1s reference at 284.4 eV. Reducibility patterns were analyzed using temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis in a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2950 instrument with a TCD detector. Catalysts were treated with a hydrogen–argon gas mixture (1:9) at 50 mL/min and ramped from 50–100°C at 15°C/min. The same instrument was utilized to quantify the catalyst basicity by CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analysis. Reduction of catalysts at 260°C for 120 min in 20% H2-N2 mixture, cooled to 50°C, and saturated with a 15% CO2-N2 mixture (50 mL/min) for 60 min trailed by He purging for 30 min. Then, after ramping the temperature from 50–450°C at 15°C/min in the flow of Helium at 40 mL/min, the desorption spectra were recorded with a TCD detector. N2O adsorption was conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2950 to study the exposed copper surface area. Standard procedures involved reducing 100 mg of the catalyst in a 20% H2-Ar mixture (25 mL/min) at 350 °C for 50 min. Afterwards, the temperature was relaxed to 80 °C with Ar purging for 20 min. N2O was introduced for 60 minutes to oxidize metallic Cu, followed by Ar flushing. Pulsed H2 at 300°C reduced Cu+1 to metallic Cu. The Cu surface area (SCu) was calculated using the equation: (ii) S Cu = ( 2 nH 2 × N ) ( 1.4 × 10 19 × W ) ( m 2 g − 1 ) where nH2​ is the H2 consumed in moles, N is Avogadro's number (6.023 × 1023 atoms per mole), 1.4 × 1019 is the no. of Cu atoms/m2, and W is the catalyst weight. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation A fixed-bed continuous flow high-pressure reactor was employed for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which had 40 cm length, 8 & 12 mm inner and outer diameters, respectively. The catalyst bed is made in the middle portion of the reactor tube and has a K-type thermocouple to measure its temperature. The catalyst (1.0 g) was granulated to a 50–70 mesh size. Before the reaction, the in-situ catalytic reduction was made with a 20% H2-N2 mixture for 4 hours at 260°C at 50 mL/min flow. The reactor was then pressurized to 50 bar through a manually controlled back-pressure regulator (BPR). The catalytic activity was recorded at 210–250°C, GHSV of 6000 mL/g.cat/hr, and 50 bar pressure. The feed gas (CO2:H2:N2=20:60:20) was regulated by the mass flow meters (MFCs). Online product analysis was performed with an Agilent 7890B RGA. CO, CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 were investigated using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and isolated through a molecular sieve. Higher hydrocarbons were examined by flame ionization detector (FID) and isolated using an HP-PONA column, while liquid products were investigated by FID separated by a Haysep Q column. Data were recorded after 4 hours on stream. CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, and STYMethanol were estimated through the following: CO 2 conversion ( % ) = CO 2 in − CO 2 out CO 2 in × 100 Methanol Selectivity, S i ( % ) = N i ∑ ( N i ) × 100 STY Methanol ( mmol . g cat − 1 . h − 1 ) = CO 2 conversion ( % ) × Methanol Selectivity ( % ) × GHSV × 0.20 22.4 × 10 − 4 Where, CO2 in and CO2 out denote the inlet & outlet molar flow rate of CO2, Si represents the methanol selectivity, GHSV is in ml.gcat −1​.h−1, and 0.20 is the molar concentration of CO2 in the reactor inlet. 2.5 Computational approach Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.2) was utilized to obtain the CO2 adsorption energies over the various Cu/ZnO model surfaces by the periodic plane-wave DFT approach [42]. The Revised Perdew-Burke-Erbzerhof (RPBE) [43] The Ultrasoft Pseudopotentials are used in conjunction with the GGA exchange-correlation function [44]. The plane-wave basis sets were trimmed to 396 eV as the cut-off energy. The energy and force convergence thresholds for structure optimizations are established at 1 × 10–6 eV and 0.05 eV/Å. A three-layer ZnO(001) surface slab was modeled for the calculations, where a Cu13 metal nanocluster was grafted over the ZnO(001) surfaces to obtain Cu13/ZnO(001) catalyst surface, named Cu13-ZnO as shown in Fig. 9b. This model was modified by replacing one Cu atom from the Cu13 cluster with an atom of Pd, labeled as Pd1Cu12-ZnO. In contrast, it was altered by replacing three more Cu atoms with Pd atoms near the previous Pd atom to get the Pd4Cu9-ZnO surface. The lowest two layers of the surface slabs were fixed throughout the structure optimization calculations, whereas the top first layer and the adsorbates were left to stabilize. A 25 Å vacuum was applied on the z-axis for all the surface slabs. The adsorption energy (Eads) of the CO2 over model Cu/ZnO(001) and the Pd modified Cu/ZnO(001) surfaces are calculated using the equation: (iii) E ads = E surface + ads − ( E surface + E ads , gas ) Where Esurface+ads, Esurface, and Eads,gas represents the energy of adsorbed species on the Cu/ZnO(001) surface and the Pd modified surface of Cu/ZnO(001); the surface of basic model Cu/ZnO(001) and the Pd modified basic model Cu/ZnO(001) and energy of adsorbed species i.e CO2 in the gaseous phase, respectively. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 X-Ray diffraction X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to distinguish the metallic phases and evaluate the crystallinity of the prepared catalysts. The diffractograms in Fig. 1 show the catalyst states before and after reduction. Initially, the catalysts showed peaks characteristic of tetragonal zirconia (t-ZrO2) at 2θ angles of 30.39°, 50.67°, and 60.29°, associated with the (101), (112), and (211) planes (JCPDS No. 88–1007). This confirms the presence of t-ZrO2 in the bulk metal oxide matrix, which helps improve the catalyst's structural and thermal stability. Additionally, CuO peaks were observed at 35.48°, 38.69°, 48.89°, 62.98°, 68.03°, and 75.12°, associated with the (002), (111), (202), (113), (220), and (222) planes (JCPDS No. 89–2531), indicating the successful incorporation of copper oxide into the catalyst structure. Peaks for ZnO were also identified at 31.70°, 34.51°, 36.18°, and 56.59°, associated with the (100), (002), (101), and (110) planes (JCPDS No. 36–1451). Interestingly, ZnO and CuO peaks overlap within the 2θ range of 34.2°–36.7°, indicating a less ordered CuO–ZnO matrix arrangement. This overlap suggests that ZnO may be partially integrated into the CuO lattice, forming well-mixed CuO–ZnO regions. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis supports this finding, as no distinct ZnO phase was observed. Such structural integration is consistent with mixed oxide systems where intermetallic synergy enhances electron transfer, surface basicity, and catalytic activity for CO2 hydrogenation [45]. The XRD patterns showed no new peaks for Pd-modified catalysts compared to the unmodified catalyst (CZZPd0), indicating that Pd was highly distributed within the bulk structure. The absence of distinct Pd-related peaks indicates that the low amount of Pd is either present as highly dispersed nanoparticles or integrated into the CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 structure, which prevents the formation of large Pd particles that XRD can possibly detect [46]. Upon reduction (Fig. 1b), the intensity of the CuO peak significantly decreased. New diffraction peaks emerged at 43.73°, 50.51°, and 74.30°, associated with (220), (200), and (111) planes of crystalline Cu0 (JCPDS No. 04–0836), indicating the reduction of CuO to metallic copper [47]. The slight variation in the intensity of Cu0 peaks among the different catalysts suggests differences in Cu0 particle sizes. Notably, the Cu0 peaks were sharper in CZZPd0 catalyst compared to the Pd-doped ones, indicating that Cu0 crystallite sizes were larger without Pd and became smaller with Pd addition. This suggests that Pd acts as a promoter, facilitating the formation of relatively smaller Cu particles during reduction, thereby decreasing the crystallinity of Cu0. Moreover, no notable changes were detected in the intensity of ZnO peaks, suggesting that the oxidation state of zinc remained unchanged and stable throughout the preparation process. This observation concomitates with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, confirming their preservation of oxidation states. However, in the reduced catalysts, the peak intensities of ZnO and ZrO2 decreased with increasing Pd loading. This decrease suggests that Pd incorporation alters the structural environment of ZnO and ZrO2 within the bulk metal oxide matrix, potentially affecting the dispersion and electronic properties of the active Cu sites [48]. These structural modifications could influence the overall catalytic performance by modifying the surface chemistry and active site accessibility. 3.2 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 2 ) highlight the reduction behavior of Cu species in Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts with varying Pd loadings (0–3%) and reveal the influence of Pd-induced hydrogen spillover. For the CZZPd0 catalyst, two separate reduction peaks were observed: 171°C for dispersed Cu species and 216°C for bulk CuO [49], with minimal influence of hydrogen spillover. Upon introducing 1% Pd (CZZPd1), a single reduction peak appeared at 178°C, indicating uniform reduction facilitated by Pd-Cu interactions and the initiation of hydrogen spillover. The temperature drop demonstrates enhanced reducibility due to the Pd sites activating hydrogen and transferring it to CuO [28,50]. This indicates that palladium modification substantially facilitated the CuO reduction [51]. At 2% Pd (CZZPd2), the reduction temperature decreased further to 150°C, accompanied by a sharper and more intense peak. However, at 3% Pd (CZZPd3), the reduction temperature slightly increased to 152°C, and the broadening of the peak. It suggested uneven Pd distribution and Cu agglomeration, which partially hindered the hydrogen spillover effect and reduced reduction efficiency. It is associated with the surface interaction of palladium with Cu²⁺/Cu⁺ species, which may hinder further adsorption of H2 in CZZPd3 due to uneven distribution and accumulation of palladium, leading to slower reduction [52–54]. The H2 consumption data (Table 2 ) supports these observations. While CZZPd3 exhibits high H2 uptake, structural limitations such as larger Cu particle sizes and disrupted Cu-Pd interfaces lower the reduction efficiency. Conversely, CZZPd2 achieves the most effective hydrogen spillover and reducibility due to smaller Cu particle sizes and better dispersion. These reduction characteristics correlate with catalytic performance. Lower reduction temperatures and higher H2 consumption directly enhance CO2 conversion by increasing the availability of dispersed Cu0 sites. In CZZPd2, the superior reduction behavior stabilizes Cu0 and Cu⁺ active sites critical for methanol synthesis. In contrast, CZZPd3 suffers from agglomeration and uneven Pd distribution, resulting in over-hydrogenation of methanol intermediates to methane. These observations show that 2% Pd represents the optimal loading, balancing hydrogen spillover, reducibility, and structural properties to achieve efficient interaction between copper species and palladium. 3.3 N2-physisorption study All synthesized catalysts exhibited Type-IV reversible isotherms with Type-H3 hysteresis loops, characteristic of mesoporous materials, as shown in Fig. 3 . These profiles confirm the presence of mesopores in all catalysts, which are essential for efficient gas diffusion and enhanced catalytic performance in CO₂ hydrogenation processes. Adding Pd to the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts resulted in a noticeable reduction in surface area compared to the unmodified catalyst (CZZPd0). Specifically, the catalyst surface area reduced from 28.5 m2/g (CZZPd0) to 27.8 m2/g (CZZPd1), 26.4 m2/g (CZZPd2), and further to 24.3 m2/g (CZZPd3) (Table 2). This decrease is due to the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles across the catalyst surface and within its pores, partially blocking the pore entrances and reducing the available surface area for adsorption and reaction. The effect was strongest in CZZPd3, which had the lowest surface area. However, the impact of Pd loading on the pore structure remains minimal at lower Pd loadings (1–2%), as observed in CZZPd1 and CZZPd2, where Pd dispersion is relatively uniform. At these loadings, Cu particle size decreases from 8.5 nm (CZZPd0) to 6.7 nm (CZZPd2), enhancing metal dispersion and active site exposure. At higher Pd loading (CZZPd3), the decrease in pore volume and surface area becomes more noticeable, likely due to Pd agglomeration and the filling of smaller pores, which are critical for active site accessibility. The surface area reduction aligns with the observed increase in Cu particle size from 7.4 nm (CZZPd1) to 8 nm (CZZPd3) (Table 2), indicating Pd's role in modifying the structural properties of Cu-based catalysts. Larger Cu crystallites at 3% Pd lead to a decrease in exposed Cu0 active sites, reducing the catalyst's ability to adsorb and activate CO2 effectively [55]. The reduced pore volume and surface area are consistent with structural changes observed in XRD and HRTEM data, where Pd incorporation impacts Cu dispersion and particle size distribution. The ability of Pd to enhance reducibility via hydrogen spillover partially compensates for the reduced surface area, however, at excessive loadings (3% Pd), agglomeration and pore blockage diminish these benefits. These findings highlight the delicate balance required in Pd loading to maintain optimal textural properties. At 2% Pd (CZZPd2), the minimal impact on pore structure, coupled with enhanced Cu dispersion and reducibility, ensures superior catalytic performance, as opposed to excessive Pd loading, which leads to detrimental structural effects. 3.4 CO2 TPD The CO2-TPD study in Fig. 4 shows three types of adsorption sites for the synthesized catalysts. Weak basic (WB) sites at 195–320 °C correspond to CO2 adsorbing on Cu surfaces or hydroxyl groups. Moderate basic (MB) sites, in the 330–450 °C range, are related to element-oxygen pairs like Pd-O, Zr-O, and Zn-O, offering stronger CO2 binding. Strong basic (SB) sites at 500–620 °C come from low-coordinated O2- species and oxygen vacancies, critical for CO₂ activation at higher temperatures [41,52,56,57]. These oxygen vacancies, formed during catalyst reduction, are essential for CO2 adsorption and activation, especially at MB and SB sites, where CO2 adsorbs predominantly at Cu active sites at low temperatures and in oxygen vacancies at higher temperatures, with the latter being more significant [58–63]. The CO2 adsorption capacities of the catalysts (Table 2) increase with Pd loading: 0.79 mmol/g (CZZPd0), 0.82 mmol/g (CZZPd1), 0.93 mmol/g (CZZPd2), and 1.21 mmol/g (CZZPd3). At 1% Pd (CZZPd1), the slight increase in adsorption is due to improved Cu dispersion and generation of oxygen vacancies. At 2% Pd (CZZPd2), adsorption increases further due to enhanced surface basicity and efficient hydrogen spillover, providing better CO2 activation. However, at 3% Pd (CZZPd3), the highest CO2 adsorption is observed. Still, structural issues like uneven Pd distribution and Cu particle agglomeration reduce methanol-specific active sites, leading to higher methane formation. The trends in CO2 adsorption align with catalytic performance. While 3% Pd provides the highest CO2 adsorption, it also causes excessive basicity and structural issues, reducing methanol selectivity. On the other hand, 2% Pd (CZZPd2) balances CO2 adsorption, basicity, and structural uniformity, resulting in the best catalytic performance. 3.5 XPS The surface chemistry and electronic states of the reduced catalysts were analyzed using XPS, focusing on Cu2p, Zn2p, Zr3d, Pd3d, O1s, and Cu-LMM spectra. Fig. 5(a-f) displays the respective XPS spectra, providing insights into the electronic and chemical environments of the active components. In Fig. 5a, the Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 peaks in the 931–935 eV and 951–955 eV binding energy confirm the presence of Cu+/Cu0 species [64]. Due to the close binding energy difference (0.1–0.2 eV) between Cu+ and Cu0, their precise differentiation is challenging [65]. The satellite peaks observed in the 940–943 eV range suggest the co-existence of Cu+/Cu2+ species, particularly in catalysts with lower Pd loading [66]. In Pd-modified catalysts, the binding energy of Cu shifted about 1.5 eV lower. This shows that Pd changes the electronic properties of Cu, inflencing its energy state. The Cu-LMM Auger spectrum (Fig. 5f) further confirms the presence of Cu+ at 570 eV and Cu0 at 568 eV, characteristic of strong metal-oxide interactions and the stabilization of Cu+ species [67]. This stabilization is particularly evident in CZZPd2, which also shows the highest Cu dispersion (3.2%) (Table 2), contributing to its superior catalytic performance. Fig. 5b represents Zn2p3/2 and Zn2p1/2 peaks at 1022 eV and 1045 eV correspond to Zn2+ and ZnO. Similarly, Fig. 5c shows Zr3d5/2 and Zr3d3/2 peaks at 182 eV and 184 eV, confirming the presence of ZrO2. The binding energies for Zn and Zr remained consistent across all Pd-modified catalysts, indicating minimal changes in their chemical environments and structural stability despite Pd incorporation. Fig. 5d highlights Pd3d5/2 and Pd3d3/2 peaks at 346 eV and 332.5 eV. These peaks slightly shifted due to interactions with CuO, which reduced Pd's electron density. The highest peak intensity was seen in CZZPd2, correlating with its highest Pd dispersion (3.2%) compared to CZZPd1 (2.1%) and CZZPd3 (2%). Good dispersion of Pd improves hydrogen spillover and catalyst reducibility, which aligns with TPR results. Lower intensity of Pd peaks observed at higher Pd loading (CZZPd3) suggests partial migration of Pd into the bulk, reducing the amount available on the surface [68,69]. The O1s spectra (Fig. 5e) was analyzed to examine the role of oxygen vacancies in CO2 activation and metal-oxide interactions. Three distinct oxygen species were identified: lattice oxygen (OL) at 529.65 eV, adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) at 530.83 eV, and surface hydroxyl groups (OH) at 532 eV. The area percent ratio of Oads/OL increased with Pd loading, as shown in Table 3 , peaking at 1.23 for CZZPd2 before slightly declining to 1.07 for CZZPd3. This trend indicates that Pd doping enhances the density of adsorbed oxygen species, which are critical for CO2 adsorption and activation. The increased Oads content in CZZPd2 correlates with its superior catalytic performance, as adsorbed oxygen species provide active sites for CO2 binding and activation, facilitating intermediate stabilization during hydrogenation. Simultaneously, the lattice oxygen content (OL) decreased with Pd loading, reflecting the presence of oxygen vacancies particularly prominent in CZZPd2. These oxygen vacancies are crucial in stabilizing Cu+ species and enhancing the strong interfacial interactions, as observed in H2-TPR and CO2-TPD analysis. In contrast, the slight decline in Oads/OL for CZZPd3 suggests that excessive Pd loading disrupts the optimal oxygen vacancy formation, leading to reduced methanol selectivity and increased byproduct formation. This suggests the critical role of adsorbed oxygen species and oxygen vacancies in achieving efficient CO2 hydrogenation. Pd incorporation significantly influences the electronic state of Cu and Pd, stabilizes oxygen vacancies, and enhances Cu+ and Pd-O interactions. Among the catalysts, CZZPd2 demonstrates the most favorable balance of surface dispersion, electronic interactions, and oxygen species, contributing to its superior reducibility and catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation. 3.6 HRTEM HRTEM analysis was conducted to observe the particle morphology of CZZPd2 catalyst. Images of the fresh, reduced, and spent catalyst samples are shown in Figs. 6 a, 6b, and 6c, respectively. Elemental mapping (Fig. 6d) confirms uniform distribution of Cu, Zn, Zr, and Pd species across the catalyst surface. EDS analysis highlights the distribution of Pd nanoparticles on the catalyst surface, supporting Pd's role in enhancing active site accessibility and promoting uniform interactions. The fresh catalyst (Fig. 6a) shows nearly spherical particles, indicating a well-defined morphology. The calculated fringe distances of 0.181 nm, 0.234 nm, and 0.253 nm attributed to the (112) plane of tetragonal ZrO2 and the (111) and (002) planes of CuO, respectively. Upon reduction, as shown in Fig. 6b, these CuO particles are converted into metallic Cu particles, exhibiting a fringe distance of 0.208 nm, associated with the (111) plane of Cu0. The reduced catalyst's average metallic Cu particle size was approximately 8 nm, consistent with particle sizes derived from XRD and BET analyses. The relatively small particle size indicates effective dispersion of Cu0, likely facilitated by Pd, which promotes hydrogen spillover and enhances metal-oxide interactions. The absence of ZnO particles suggests a well-mixed CuO-ZnO domain, aligning with the XRD analysis. In the spent catalyst (Fig. 6c), metallic Cu particles exhibit slight growth, with an average particle size of 10 nm. This minimal increase can be attributed to prolonged reaction conditions leading to partial sintering of Cu0 particles [70,71]. However, even after the reaction, the relatively small size of Cu particles demonstrates the effectiveness of the ZnO/ZrO2 matrix in mitigating sintering through strong interfacial interactions. The Pd addition maintained the structural integrity by promoting efficient hydrogen spillover, which helps regenerate active sites and limits excessive particle growth. Thus, in CZZPd2, Pd enhances Cu0 stability, slightly increases particle size from 8 to 10 nm, and supports catalytic performance by forming a well-mixed CuO-ZnO structure. 4 Catalytic activity The activity of the synthesized Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 systems with varying Pd loadings (1, 2, and 3 wt.% Pd) was evaluated across a temperature range of 210–250 °C under 50 bar pressure and a H2:CO2 ratio of 3:1, with a GHSV of 6000 mL/g.cat/hr, shown in Fig. 7 . The results reveal distinct trends in CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, CO selectivity, CH4 selectivity, and STYMethanol as a function of both temperature and Pd loading, offering insights into the role of Pd in optimizing catalytic performance. For the undoped catalyst (CZZPd0), CO2 conversion was increased with the temperature rise, from 13.8% at 210 °C to 21.5% at 250 °C. This trend is due to enhanced thermal energy that provides more energy and facilitates CO₂ activation and hydrogenation reaction more effectively. Methanol selectivity decreased significantly with temperature, dropping from 53% at 210 °C to 41% at 250 °C. CH4 selectivity followed a declining trend, from 0.7% at 210 °C to 0.1% at 250 °C, reflecting the dominance of RWGS reaction over methanation with the rise in temperatures. Correspondingly, CO selectivity increased from 46.3% at 210 °C to 59% at 250 °C, reflecting the thermodynamic shift toward RWGS over methanol synthesis. The STYMethanol for CZZPd0 increased from 3.92 mmol/g.cat/hr at 210 °C to 4.82 mmol/g.cat/hr at 250 °C. While higher temperatures improved CO2 conversion, the decline in methanol selectivity limited the overall methanol productivity. This performance highlights the inability of the undoped catalyst to stabilize methanol-specific intermediates like formate and methoxide, leading to lower methanol yields. After adding 1wt.% Pd to the CZZ, CZZPd1 showed enhanced CO2 conversion at each temperature, rising from 14.5% at 210 °C to 22.5% at 250 °C. This improvement is attributed to Pd's role in promoting hydrogen spillover, which accelerates the reduction of CuO to Cu0 and facilitates CO2 activation [72,73]. Methanol selectivity, while higher than CZZPd0 at all temperatures, decreased with temperature rise, dropping from 64% at 210 °C to 51% at 250 °C. CH4 selectivity, starting at 1.6% at 210 °C, decreased to 0.5% at 250 °C. The decline in methanol selectivity and CH4 selectivity, accompanied by an increase in CO selectivity (34.4% at 210 °C to 48.5% at 250 °C), indicates the thermodynamic favorability of RWGS with increased temperatures. STYMethanol for CZZPd1 improved significantly over CZZPd0, reaching 6.19 mmol/g.cat/hr at 240 °C before slightly declining to 6.15 mmol/g.cat/hr at 250 °C. This indicates that 1% Pd loading enhances methanol production efficiency, particularly at intermediate temperatures, by stabilizing active Cu sites and promoting the formation of methanol intermediates. For CZZPd2, CO2 conversion increased from 15% at 210 °C to 23% at 250 °C, suggesting that 2 wt.% Pd further facilitates CO2 activation through enhanced hydrogen spillover. Methanol selectivity remained significantly higher than CZZPd0 and CZZPd1, starting at 74% at 210 °C and maintaining 64% at 240 °C before declining to 60% at 250 °C. CH4 selectivity decreased from 2.66% at 210 °C to 1.2% at 250 °C, whereas CO selectivity increased from 23.34% at 210 °C to 38.8% at 250 °C. The simultaneous decline in methanol and CH4 selectivity and rise in CO selectivity were similar trends observed for CZZPd0 & CZZPd1. STYMethanol for CZZPd2 reached 7.54 mmol/g.cat/hr at 240 °C. At 250 °C, the STYMethanol slightly decreased to 7.39 mmol/g.cat/hr due to the joint effects of reduced methanol selectivity and increased CO formation. The 3 wt.% Pd catalyst (CZZPd3) achieved the highest CO2 conversion among all samples, increasing from 16.0% at 210 °C to 23.5% at 250 °C, but the increase was insignificant compared to CZZPd2. Methanol selectivity declined sharply compared to CZZPd2, from 68% at 210 °C to 55% at 250 °C. CH4 selectivity, the highest among all catalysts at lower temperatures, started at 4.75% at 210 °C and decreased to 2.1% at 250 °C. It indicates that the abundance of Pd might disrupt the balance of Cu active sites, resulting in excessive hydrogenation even at lower temperatures. Consequently, CO selectivity increased from 27.25% at 210 °C to 42.9% at 250 °C, reflecting the increasing favorability of RWGS at elevated temperatures. STYMethanol for CZZPd3 reached 6.92 mmol/g.cat/hr at 240 °C, lower than observed for CZZPd2 but slightly declined to 6.87 mmol/g.cat/hr at 250 °C, as the drop in methanol selectivity balanced the gains in CO2 conversion. The catalyst's performance suggests that among all tested catalysts, the 2 wt.% Pd catalyst (CZZPd2) at 240 °C achieves the most balanced performance, with CO2 conversion of 22%, CH3OH selectivity of 64%, and STYMethanol of 7.54 mmol/g.cat/hr. The comparison with CZZPd3 highlights that while 3 wt.% Pd achieves higher CO2 conversion but excessive Pd loading disrupts the balance of active sites, leading to lower methanol selectivity and increased CH4 formation. The 2% Pd loading optimally enhances hydrogen spillover, stabilizes Cu active sites, and balances the competing RWGS and methanation reactions, making it the most effective catalyst for selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The apparent activation energies (Ea) under the controlled kinetic regime were also determined for methanol formation using the Arrhenius equation: (iv) k = Ae − Ea / RT where, k = Rate constant A = Pre-exponential factor R = Universal Gas Constant (8.314 J/mol.K) T = Absolute Temperature The slope of the linearized Arrhenius plot (ln k vs 1/T) was used to estimate the Ea for each catalyst (Fig. 8 ). The calculated activation energies for methanol formation are 58, 56, 52, and 55 kJ/mol for the CZZPd0, CZZPd1, CZZPd2, and CZZPd3 catalysts. The lowest Ea (52 kJ/mol) was observed for CZZPd2, which correlates with its superior methanol STY (7.54 mmol/g·cat/hr at 240 °C). The reduced Ea for CZZPd2 can be attributed to its optimal Pd loading (2 wt.%), which enhances the electronic interactions between Pd and Cu active sites, promoting hydrogen spillover and efficient balance of important reaction intermediates, such as formate (HCOO⁻) and methoxide (CH3O⁻) [55,74–76]. These intermediates facilitate a lower energy pathway for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH [77]. In contrast, CZZPd1 (undoped catalyst) exhibited the highest Ea (58 kJ/mol), reflecting the limited ability of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 alone to stabilize intermediates or accelerate reaction kinetics. For CZZPd1 and CZZPd3, the Ea values (56 kJ/mol and 55 kJ/mol, respectively) indicate suboptimal Pd effects. CZZPd1 (1 wt.% Pd) has insufficient Pd to fully enhance hydrogen spillover and active site stabilization. At the same time, CZZPd3 (3 wt.% Pd) suffers from excessive Pd loading, leading to particle agglomeration and disruption of metal-oxide interactions, which partially increases the energy barrier for methanol synthesis. The apparent activation energy data support the structure-activity relationship findings, with the CZZPd2 catalyst exhibiting the lowest Ea due to its optimized Cu-Pd synergy, which promotes a highly efficient reaction pathway for methanol synthesis. This highlights the critical role of precise Pd loading in tailoring the activation energy and enhancing catalytic performance. A comprehensive comparison is shown in Table 4 , which summarizes previously reported benchmark catalysts under similar reaction conditions. It presents key performance metrics—CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, STYMethanol, and activation energy (Ea), Methanol)—for the synthesized CZZPd2 catalyst alongside literature-reported catalysts. The comparison highlights the competitive efficiency of our catalyst in terms of higher CO2 conversion, favorable methanol selectivity, and superior STYMethanol under mild reaction conditions. 5 DFT study The CO2 adsorption energy on Cu13/ZnO, Pd1Cu12/ZnO, and Pd4Cu9/ZnO surfaces was calculated using DFT to examine the influence of palladium (Pd) on the Cu/ZnO surface for CH3OH formation. The optimized surface of the ZnO(001) geometry is illustrated in Fig. 9 a. A Cu13 nanocluster was grafted on the ZnO (001) surface to obtain the Cu13/ZnO(001) catalyst surface, as depicted in Fig. 9b. Multiple Cu-O bonds in the geometry-optimized structure of the Cu13/ZnO(001) surface suggested a strong metal-oxide interaction of Cu13 nanoparticle over the ZnO(001) surface, as shown in Fig. 9b. The Pd1Cu12/ZnO(001) model surface was formed by substituting one Cu atom on the Cu13/ZnO(001) interface with a Pd atom, as shown in Fig. 9c, and the Pd4Cu9/ZnO(001) surface was developed by replacing four Cu atoms with Pd atoms, as depicted in Fig. 9d. 5.1 CO2 adsorption The adsorption of CO2 was examined across all Cu/ZnO and Pd-modified Cu/ZnO model surfaces, revealing that the ZnO (001) surface itself was inactive for CO2 activation, as CO2 was not adsorbed on it, as shown in Fig. 10 . In contrast, the Cu13 nanocluster grafted on the ZnO (001) surface provides a uniform metallic atmosphere having an average Cu-Cu bond length of 2.5 Å, as shown in Fig. 9b. The Cu atoms primarily interact with ZnO, having an average Cu-Zn bond length of 2.6 Å, forming active sites at the interface, which was active for CO2 adsorption [78], illustrated in Fig. 11 a. The CO2 molecule was observed to adsorb strongly at the interface in a V-shaped configuration, with an O-C-O bond angle of 128°. This adsorption involved the formation of Zn-O and Cu-C bonds, with measured bond distances of 2.12 Å and 2.11 Å. The corresponding adsorption energy for the CO2 adsorption on the Cu13/ZnO (001) surface was calculated to be -0.35 eV, suggesting an exothermic process. Fig. 9c illustrates that replacing one Cu atom from the previous cluster with a Pd atom significantly distorted the geometry of the cluster with an average Cu-Pd bond distance of 2.62 Å. In contrast, the distance of the Zn-Pd bond was measured to be 2.78 Å. CO2 exhibited strong adsorption at the active site of the Pd1Cu12/ZnO catalyst, forming Pd-Cu and Zn -O bonds distances of 2.07 Å and 2.12 Å (Fig. 11b). The bond angle of O-C-O was observed to be increased up to 136°. The process released an adsorption energy of -0.42 eV during the CO2 adsorption on the Pd1Cu12/ZnO surface, showing 0.07 eV more exothermic surface than the Cu13/ZnO. The geometry distortion may increase the surface area exposed to the adsorbate (CO2). In addition, introducing Pd enhances the transfer of electrons to CO2 because of Pd's higher electronegativity. This electron transfer polarizes the CO2 molecule, increasing the strength of the C=O bond interaction and enabling easier CO2 activation [79,80]. Substituting four Cu atoms with Pd results in further distortion with an average Cu-Pd, Pd-Pd, and Zn-Pd bond distances of 2.63 Å, 2.8 Å, and 2.61 Å, respectively (Fig. 9d). The CO2 adsorption on the Pd4Cu9/ZnO surface was in a pattern quite similar to the previous two surfaces. However, the O-C-O bond angle was expanded to 138°, while Pd-Cu and Zn-O bond distances were determined to be 2.04 Å and 2.12 Å, respectively. The CO2 binding energy on the Pd4Cu9/ZnO catalyst was found to be -0.49 eV, which was 0.07 eV and 0.14 eV higher than on the Pd1Cu12/ZnO and Cu13/ZnO models, respectively. Pd atoms created a bimetallic synergy with Cu atoms at the interface, significantly enhancing the electronic density around the active sites and further influencing CO2 binding geometry by creating a stronger interaction with the C=O bond of CO2. This reduces the energy barrier for CO2 activation and favors the formation of intermediates like formate or carboxylate species [81,82]. All the outcomes considered, the CO2 adsorption energy trend across the studied model set was found to correspond with the following pattern: Cu13/ZnO < Pd1Cu12/ZnO/ < Pd4Cu9/ZnO, which indicated that the CO2 adsorption capacity increases with the rise in Pd loading. Increased CO2 adsorption leads to higher conversion rates. Therefore, the DFT study results correlate well with the CO2 TPD and conversion data obtained during the experiment. 6 in-situ DRIFTS For a deeper understanding of the CO2 hydrogenation mechanism, an in-situ DRIFTS analysis was conducted for the CZZPd2 catalyst. Fig. 12 shows the spectra recorded at 180 °C under the feed flow at ambient pressure, revealing various adsorbed surface species associated with CO2 activation and hydrogenation. The spectra revealed the presence of crucial adsorbed surface species involved in the CO2 hydrogenation process, with characteristic peak assignments providing valuable insights into the reaction mechanism. Methylates (CH3O⁻) were identified at ∼1075 cm-1, corresponding to weak methoxy stretching vibrations and chemisorbed protonated methylates [83,84]. Surface carbonates (CO3 2-) were detected at multiple regions: ∼1127 cm-1 (monodentate carbonates) and ∼1520–1580 cm-1, 1630–1680 cm-1 (bidentate and polydentate carbonates), indicating the presence of various carbonate coordination modes on the catalyst surface. Formates (HCOO⁻), key intermediates in the methanol synthesis pathway, exhibited distinct vibrational bands at ∼1395–1435 cm-1 (ν_as(O–C–O) asymmetric stretching) and ∼1520–1580 cm-1 (ν_s(O–C–O) symmetric stretching), with overlapping contributions from surface carbonates (CO3 2-) in ∼1520–1580 cm-1 range [83,85–87]. Formaldehyde (CH2O) was identified with vibrational peaks at ∼1476–1505 cm-1, attributed to the CH2 scissoring modes and C=O stretching [88–90]. Additionally, gaseous formaldehyde was observed at ∼1695–1770 cm-1, corresponding to the characteristic C=O stretching vibrations [91]. Bands detected in the ∼1793–1966 cm-1 range confirmed the presence of gaseous water (H2O), attributed to molecular water's bending and liberational modes in the gas phase [92]. It is also observed that no CO intermediate was detected during the DRIFTS experiment conducted at atmospheric pressure. This absence is attributed to the lack of applied pressure, as similar findings were reported in a recent study where CO was only detected when the DRIFTS experiment was performed under pressurized conditions. This confirms that reaction pressure is crucial in influencing CO production from CO2 [93]. The observed surface species align well with the possible pathway for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, which proceeds primarily through the formate (HCOO⁻) pathway [94–97]. CO2 initially adsorbs on the catalyst's active sites, forming bicarbonate and carbonate species. These are converted to formate intermediates and further hydrogenated to methoxide (CH3O⁻) species before being reduced to methanol. The CZZPd2 catalyst demonstrated well-defined formate (HCOO⁻) and methoxide (CH3O⁻) peaks at 180°C, indicating that Pd incorporation facilitates the activation of CO2 and promotes the formation of these critical intermediates at lower temperatures. The presence of Pd enhances hydrogen spillover from Pd sites to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2, reducing the energy barrier for CO2 activation and hydrogenation. This is consistent with the H2-TPR and CO2-TPD analysis. The formate pathway is particularly significant because it minimizes the formation of byproducts, such as CO and CH4, and favors selective methanol synthesis. The strong CH₃O⁻ and HCOO⁻ peaks show that Pd loading played crucial role in improving the catalyst surface for CO₂ hydrogenation. This optimal Pd content allows efficient hydrogen spillover and better use of active sites, helping to form essential intermediates. Higher Pd loading, as seen in other analyses, could cause structural issues like reduced dispersion and agglomeration, disrupting active sites and affecting the hydrogenation process. These findings confirm that incorporating Pd into the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst enhances its ability to activate and hydrogenate CO2 efficiently, favoring methanol production through the formate pathway. The in-situ DRIFTS results complement the structural and adsorption insights from XRD, TPR, XPS, and CO2-TPD analyses, providing a comprehensive understanding of the catalytic behavior of CZZPd2 for CO2 hydrogenation. The proposed mechanism for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH on CZZPd2 is shown in Fig. 14 . It begins with the CO2 adsorption onto oxygen vacancies (Ov) on the ZnO/ZrO2 matrix or near Cu⁺ sites, forming partially charged carbonate‐type intermediates stabilized by the surface basicity. Simultaneously, hydrogen dissociation on Pd nanoparticles and subsequent spillover provided a local reservoir of reactive hydrogen (H*) that migrates to Cu and oxide domains. These H atoms hydrogenate the CO2‐derived intermediates stepwise: initially, formate (HCOO⁻) species are formed, as indicated by characteristic bands in the DRIFTS spectra. The formate then undergoes further hydrogenation on Cu+ and Cu0 sites to form formaldehyde (CH2O), which appears briefly before converting to methoxide (CH3O⁻). Methoxide is the critical precursor to methanol, with DRIFTS data showing distinct signals for CH3O⁻ on Cu+/oxide interfaces. Finally, the methoxide intermediate is hydrogenated and desorbs from the surface as methanol. Throughout this cycle, Pd plays a dual role: it enhances the reduction and dispersion of Cu, thereby stabilizing the critical Cu+ sites necessary for formate and methoxide formation, and it promotes efficient H2 activation and spillover, ensuring a steady supply of active H* to drive each hydrogenation step. The CZZPd2 catalyst achieves high CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity by balancing these processes while avoiding excessive over‐hydrogenation to undesired methane. 7 Structure-activity relationship The structure-activity relationship of as-synthesized catalysts with varying Pd loadings (1 to 3wt.%) was thoroughly investigated using N2O titration, BET, XRD, TEM, XPS, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR, and in-situ DRIFTS. These techniques provided a comprehensive understanding of how Pd loading modifies metal-oxide interactions, Cu dispersion, and electronic properties and how these changes influence their activity for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. N2O titration showed that Pd increases Cu dispersion, with CZZPd2 having the highest dispersion (3.2%) compared to 1.36% for CZZPd0. However, when Pd loading increased to 3 wt.% (CZZPd3), Cu dispersion dropped to 2%, indicating that excessive Pd causes agglomeration of Cu particles, reducing active surface sites. A similar trend was observed in the Cu surface area, which peaked at 19.5 m2/g for CZZPd2, however dropped to 14 m2/g for CZZPd3, confirming that excessive Pd weakens the metal-oxide interactions that help keep Cu particles well-distributed. The XRD-derived Cu particle sizes confirmed that CZZPd2 had the smallest Cu crystallite size (6.7 nm) compared with CZZPd0 (8.5 nm) and CZZPd3 (8 nm). TEM analysis further confirmed that CZZPd2 exhibited well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles (∼8 nm), optimizing metal-oxide interactions and Cu+/Cu0 ratio for methanol synthesis, which aligns closely with the XRD-based particle size estimate. In contrast, the larger Cu particle size in CZZPd3 is due to Pd-induced Cu sintering, which reduced the dispersion of active sites, thereby lowered the methanol selectivity and increased methane formation. BET analysis showed a consistent decline in total catalyst surface area with increasing Pd loading, from 28.5 m2/g for CZZPd0 to 24.3 m2/g for CZZPd3. This reduction is primarily due to increased Pd incorporation affecting the morphology of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2. While pore size (3.54–3.57 nm) and pore volume (0.1–0.12 cm3/g) remained relatively stable, the slight reduction in pore volume for CZZPd3 suggests partial pore blockage due to excessive Pd content, restricting access to active sites and lowering methanol productivity. These findings highlight the importance of balancing Pd content to prevent structural changes that could hinder catalytic efficiency. CO2-TPD demonstrated that Pd doping enhances CO2 adsorption by increasing the density of oxygen vacancies (OV) in ZrO2, thereby improving CO2 activation. CZZPd0 exhibited the lowest CO2 adsorption capacity (0.79 mmol/g), indicating limited surface basicity and weak Cu-ZrO2 interactions. Pd doping increased CO2 adsorption to 0.93 mmol/g for CZZPd2, reflecting the optimal balance of surface basicity and electronic interactions. However, at 3 wt.% Pd (CZZPd3), CO2 adsorption increased further (1.21 mmol/g), but this also promoted excessive hydrogenation pathways, increasing CH4 selectivity. These results confirm that oxygen vacancy formation in ZrO2, coupled with Pd-Cu interactions, is essential for stabilizing CO2-derived intermediates like formate (HCOO⁻) and methoxide (CH3O⁻), which are crucial for selective methanol synthesis. XPS analysis further validated that CZZPd2 exhibits a stabilized Cu oxidation state, ensuring efficient CO2 activation and intermediate stabilization, whereas CZZPd3 showed an excessive reduction of Cu+ to Cu0, leading to increase in methane formation. H2-TPR data confirmed that Pd significantly enhances CuO reducibility via hydrogen spillover effects regulated by Pd-Cu-ZnO interactions. H2 consumption increased from 11.23 cm3/g (CZZPd0) to 12.03 cm3/g (CZZPd2), reflecting improved hydrogen utilization due to Pd-assisted Cu reduction. The reduction temperature for CuO dropped from ∼216 °C (CZZPd0) to ∼150 °C (CZZPd2), confirming that Pd facilitates CuO reduction and hydrogen activation. Although CZZPd3 showed slightly higher hydrogen consumption (12.19 cm3/g), excessive hydrogen spillover disrupted active site balance, promoting RWGS (CO formation) and CH4 selectivity. These findings indicate that precisely controlled Pd incorporation is essential to maintain optimal hydrogenation efficiency while avoiding side reactions. XRD patterns showed no new crystalline phases with Pd doping but highlighted increased Cu crystallite size for CZZPd3, suggesting Pd-induced agglomeration. In contrast, the CZZPd2 exhibited optimized Cu crystallite size and peak broadening, indicative of a stable Cu+/Cu0 ratio crucial for methanol selectivity. TEM analysis confirmed that uniform distribution of Pd nanoparticles improve the catalyst stability by preventing Cu agglomeration and further strengthen the interplay between Pd, Cu, ZnO, and ZrO2 in maintaining catalytic efficiency. In-situ DRIFTS analysis provided insights into the reaction mechanism by revealing the presence and stability of key intermediates. For CZZPd2, the strong signals of formate (HCOO⁻, 1395–1435 cm-1 and 1520–1580 cm-1) and methoxide (CH3O⁻, 1075 cm-1), and formaldehyde (CH2O, 1476–1505 cm-1) were observed, indicating that Pd incorporation facilitates the stabilization of these intermediates. The balanced synergy between Cu and Pd in CZZPd2 optimizes the availability of active sites and facilitates CO2 adsorption and activation, resulting in higher methanol selectivity. This is further supported by CO2-TPD, which indicates optimal CO2 adsorption and the creation of oxygen vacancies necessary for stabilizing intermediates. Additionally, XPS results confirm that the electronic structure of Cu and Pd in CZZPd2 promotes the activation of CO2 and H2, with strong interfacial interactions contributing to Cu+ stabilization. The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts correlates well with their structural and electronic properties. CZZPd2 exhibited the highest STYMethanol of 7.54 mmol/g·cat/hr at 240 °C, attributed to optimized Cu particle size, a well-balanced Cu+/Cu0 ratio, and strong Pd-Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 interactions that enhance CO2 activation and intermediate stabilization. In contrast, CZZPd3, despite achieving high CO2 adsorption and hydrogen consumption, exhibited reduced methanol selectivity due to excessive spillover and agglomeration of active sites, promoting CH4 formation. These findings demonstrate that tuning Pd loading is crucial in optimizing the catalytic properties of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2. CZZPd2, with 2 wt.% Pd, achieved the best balance of Cu dispersion, Cu+/Cu0 ratio, and CO2-derived intermediate stabilization, leading to superior catalytic performance. 8 Conclusions This study explored the impact of Pd doping in Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 (CZZ) catalysts for selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, combining experimental characterizations with kinetics & Density Functional Theory (DFT) to understand the structure-activity relationship. Pd loading significantly improved catalytic performance by modifying the electronic structure of Cu sites, promoting hydrogen spillover, and stabilizing intermediates crucial for methanol formation. CZZPd2 with 2 wt.% Pd loading was identified as the optimal system, achieving 22% CO2 conversion, 64% methanol selectivity, and a STYMethanol of 7.54 mmol/g.cat/hr at 240 °C and 50 bar, significantly outperforming both the undoped catalyst (CZZPd0) and the catalyst with higher Pd loading (CZZPd3). Characterizations showed that CZZPd2 had the highest metal dispersion (3.2%), Cu surface area (19.5 m²/g), and the smallest Cu particle size (6.7 nm), ensuring efficient active site distribution. It also exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy (Ea) for methanol formation at 52 kJ/mol, indicating its superior catalytic efficiency. This optimal performance is due to the enhanced interaction between Pd and Cu, facilitating CO2 activation, hydrogen spillover, and intermediate stabilization. In contrast, the undoped catalyst (CZZPd0) had a higher Ea (58 kJ/mol) and limited ability to stabilize intermediates. At the same time, CZZPd3 (3 wt.% Pd) suffered from particle agglomeration and increased CH4 selectivity (4.75% at 210 °C), reducing methanol efficiency. In-situ DRIFTS showed that CZZPd2 effectively stabilized key intermediates, such as formate (HCOO⁻) and methoxide (CH3O⁻), critical for methanol synthesis. CO2-TPD analysis revealed optimal CO2 adsorption and surface basicity for CZZPd2, while H2-TPR and XPS confirmed enhanced reducibility and strong electronic interactions at the Cu-Pd interface. TEM analysis showed that CZZPd2 had uniformly dispersed Pd nanoparticles, avoiding the agglomeration. DFT calculations supported these findings by demonstrating how Pd doping improved charge transfer at the Cu-Pd-ZnO interface, lowering the energy required for CO2 activation and hydrogenation. This synergy between Pd and Cu is critical for achieving high methanol selectivity and STYMethanol. However, as in CZZPd3, excessive Pd loading disrupted this balance, leading to lower methanol efficiency and higher by-product formation. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the influence of palladium (Pd) doping on Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, combining comprehensive experimental characterizations with theoretical insights. The catalysts, synthesized with varying Pd loadings (0–3 wt.%), were evaluated across 210–250 °C. Catalytic performance analysis revealed that 2 wt.% Pd (CZZPd2) demonstrated superior CO2 conversion (22%) and methanol selectivity (64%) at 240 °C, achieving the highest methanol space-time yield (7.54 mmol/g.cat/hr). Characterization techniques, including XRD, XPS, TEM, CO2-TPD, and H2-TPR, highlighted the critical role of Pd in enhancing hydrogen spillover, stabilizing Cu active sites, and promoting optimal oxygen vacancy formation, which collectively facilitated intermediate stabilization and reduced the apparent activation energy (Ea = 52 kJ/mol) for methanol synthesis. In-situ DRIFTS validated the stabilization of key reaction intermediates (formate and methoxide) on CZZPd2, correlating with its superior catalytic performance. DFT calculations provided atomic-level insights, illustrating the synergistic electronic interaction between Pd, Cu, and ZnO, which optimally lowers the energy barrier for CO2 activation and methanol formation. Excessive Pd loading (CZZPd3) led to particle agglomeration, disrupted metal-oxide interactions, and increased activation energy, reducing methanol selectivity. These findings highlight the important role of Pd in shaping the structure and electronic properties of the catalyst, making CZZPd2 as a benchmark catalyst for efficient and selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
